content:
I've listed some things for you to try.

Check you have full view and nothing is hiding: Check you have the following:

  • View > Folders > All
  • View > Threads > All

check Quick Filter Bar - do you have anything selected/highlighted? If anything is selected then click on it to uncheck.

Are you used to using Sort by > 'unthreaded' ? If yes, maybe a load of emails are hidden in collapsed threads. 'View' > 'Sort by' select 'unthreaded'

check the Archives folder to see if they have ended up in Archives.

Please note there are shortcut keys which if used can hide emails eg: K Switch on the option to view ignored threads to see if this occured:

  • View > Threads > select 'Ignored threads' (leave 'All' selected as well)

Does this show emails with a red circle in the threads column ? if yes: right click on email to see drop down menu and it will have a tick on 'ignore thread' click on 'ignore thread' to remove that setting. This action is a per email action, so if you have a few of them, it may take a while to do them all.


Is this an imap mail account? If imap: Logon to webmail account via a browser - are the emails on the server or not? Please note if emails are not seen in imap account Inbox then it is impossible for an imap account to display something that does not exist.

If you use gmail or a server that uses a gmail style set up using labels, then logon to webmail and see if the 'All Mail' folder still has those emails. You can reapply an Inbox label to an email to get it to display again in Inbox.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
re :allmail folder keep reinstalling deleted messages

Then they are not deleted. 'All Mail' is the storage of all your emails, incoming, sent and archived. It has everything.

When you choose to delete an email in a gmail imap account, it must be put into the gmail imap Trash folder (sometimes called Bin). check you are using the correct TRash folder. Logon to webmail. Delete an email and note the name of the folder which auto contains the deleted email.

In Thunderbird click on 'Trash folder so it synchronises with folder - do you see that deleted email in the imap Trash folder ? If yes, then you know that imap Trash folder is the correct folder. All is OK If no, then check you are synchronised to correct folder.

  • Right click on imap mail account name folder in Folder Pane and select: 'subscribe'
  • select the Trash folder and click on 'Unsubscribe'.
  • Maybe you see more than one Trash folder!
  • clickon OK

Back in webmail account - Does webmail account contain another Trash folder maybe below the default folders. Select Settings > see all settings and then 'Labels' On the left under 'Labels' have you got addtional Trash folders which are not the default top Trash ? If yes, then delete it as it's causing confusion.

Back in Thunderbird:

  • Right click on imap mail account name folder in Folder Pane and select: 'subscribe'
  • click on 'Refresh'
  • select the Trash folder and click on 'Subscribe'.
  • clickon OK

Check settings:

  • Account Settings > Server Settings for imap gmail account

When I delete a message:

  • select 'Move it to this folder'
  • Select 'Trash on imap gmail account'

Message Storage:

  • Select 'Clean up Expunge Unbox on Exit.' So it auto compacts and removes all old re=traces of deleted and moved emails.

Now when you delete an email it should go to the gmail imap Trash folder. Delete being clicking on a delete bin icon or delete button or delete key. Gmail will auto remove any deleted emails from the TRash after 30 days. Thus allowing you some time to retrieve an email deleted in error. But you can choose to manually right click on imap gmail Trash folder and select 'Empty Deleted' to clear it. Once email is fully gone it is also removed from 'AllMail'.

If you use the 'Shift' + 'Delete' then this deletes the message bypassing Trash (no Undo!). In effect this action removes a label, but does not delete email from AllMail. Email has been archived. Because this does not put the email in the imap Trash folder, it means you no longer see email in that imap folder, but it's not properly deleted. Note: this special type of delete is useful if you have more than one copy of email - it displays in eg: Important and Inbox, but you only want to see the one in Important. So, 'shift+Delete' on the one in Inbox, removes email from Inbox, gmail removes 'Inbox' label. Email is still seen in 'Important'. A standard 'Delete' would have removed all labels, so both copies would be deleted.
creator: Toad-Hall

creator: ian1936

content: That is not a mistake. Gmail likes to keep everything, even the trash. I encourage all users to unsubscribe from the allmail folder as it just confuses people. Gmail doesn't actually have traditional folders; instead, it uses pointers to messages to keep track of them. So, all of your mail has at least two pointers ('labels' in Gmail's vocabulary). Your inbox is in the inbox label and the allmail label, and so on.
creator: davidsk

content: I need a TB profile backup in the cloud, without any execution. But iCloud doesn't work like Google Drive. iCloud maintains an up-to-date copy of all files placed in the Desktop folder, and ignores other files--so they want you to put all your "data" in Desktop. But because the TB profile is a hidden file in Library on a mac, you can't just move it into the Desktop folder. If I copy it into Desktop, then I have two profile copies on my harddrive, and it costs me an extra 50GB of disc space on my mac. Is there no other option?
creator: danjantzen

content: Are you talking backup, or are you planning to execute from the cloud? To backup, just do it when TB is not running. And the process is to copy, not to move.

content: Safest procedure, assuming you have not moved profile from default location, is to - install TB in new PC and exit - with TB not running on old pc, copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to a USB - copy USB to same location on new PC. You will be prompted for overwrites, but that is ok. - start TB and the profile should be there.

content:
What a timely coincidence! Today, I accidentally hot the "K" and a whole thread just disappeared, seemingly without trace. There was a message about a thread being ignored, but that was just before my screen went dead (an unrelated problem) and I had to power-cycle the machine. Eventually I found the way to show "ignored" items, but not how actually to fix the "ignored" status. So Toad-Hall's answer from yesterday morning was just in time for me - thank you very much!

It all happened because a nasty little "feature" of Thunderbird: the key combination to "unread" a message on Linux (and probably on Windows, too) is Alt-M, K, U. It's very easy to type Ctrl-M, K, U, instead. Now, Ctrl-M is harmless - just a shortcut for "write a new mail". But the subsequent K is a killer: I wanted to "unread" a message exactly because it was important and I wanted to to make sure I look at it again, instead I set an "ignore" flag! Bummer.
creator: msohnius

content:
I think it may be necessary to create a bug report. I'm asking specific questions to fully understand exactly what is going on so I can give full info in the report. Could you answer each question for me even if it sounds like you've triedit before. Thanks.

Q: Please confirm you are using Thunderbird 102.14.0 Q: Is the folder which contains the email a 'Unified' folder or normal folder? Q:Does that folder have 'View' > 'Sort by' set as 'threaded' or 'unthreaded'?

Q:Please confirm the 'ignored' email is a top level email and not a subthread. Q:If you use 'threaded', does that email have threads? Is there a > indicating a collapsed thread? Q:If yes, it's threaded and collapsed, please expand the thread - is the 'ignored' email now shown as one of the subthreads or is it still the top level thread? If yes, it's now shown as a subthread - Q:When you right click on email to see drop down, does the 'ignore subthread' have a tick against it or not? Q:Regardless of whether 'ignore subthread' has a tick or not - click on 'ignore subthread' - does it remove the 'ignore' on email ?

Q:If 'threaded' try 'View' > 'Sort by' > 'unthreaded' and see if the drop down option to 'ignore thread' works. Please report on results.

Q:When you right click on email to see drop down, does the 'ignore thread' have a tick against it or not? Q:If it has a tick, click on it, then right click on email to see drop down again, does the tick still display or not?

Thanks for info.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
What OS are you using ? Windows , MAC, Linux ? What version of Thunderbird are you using?

If set a thread as ignore, deliberately or accidently, it immediately sets a red circle icon in the thread column. If I move away from folder and then return I cannot see ignored thread to see the ignored threads do this:

  • View > Threads > select 'ignored threads'

If ignored email is using sort by > 'unthreaded' OR is the top level thread in sort by 'threaded' view: In thread column, the email has the red circle denoting it is marked as an ignored thread.

  • Right click on ignored email in list/thread pane and the drop down menu it will show 'ignore thread' with a tick.
  • Left Click once on the ticked 'ignore thread' menu item.
  • In thread column the red circle is removed and that item is no longer set as ignored.

If you use 'threaded' view, and ignored thread is a subthread: The expanded thread column icon will have a small red circle against the ignored sub thread.

  • Right click on ignored email in list/thread pane and the drop down menu it will show 'ignore subthread' with a tick.
  • Left Click once on the ticked 'ignored thread' menu item.
  • In thread column the red circle is removed and that item is no longer set as ignored.

However, I have discovered a potential bug in 102.14.0 when it comes to an ignored subthread. When you right click on ignored subthread, the drop down list does not show a tick against the 'ignore subthread' item in list - but if you click on it once, the action works and removes the red circle from item.
creator: Toad-Hall
